And welcome to today's episode of the Mahabharata.
In the previous episode, we have seen the beginning of one of the key moments in the
history of the world, in the history of the Mahabharata, a pivotal point in the whole
narration of the Mahabharata epic, the game of die.
We saw how Duryodhana and Shakuni.
Duryodhana, Shakuni, Karna, and Dhritarashtra, Dushyasana, all these people combined together
to lay out a scheme, a plot, how to trap the Pandavas and take their kingdom by cheating.
Because the Pandavas were too powerful for direct confrontation.
We also saw how Yudhishthiram had a great power over the Mahabharata.
We also saw how Yudhishthiram had a great power over the Mahabharata.
We also saw how Yudhishthiram had a great power over the Mahabharata.
He was hard excited and eager to turn that game around.
He almost stepped out when Dhritarashtra killed him.
Udhishthira Maharaj was unwilling to participate in that game of dice.
But he was bound by the instructions of his elder, Dhritarashtra.
Even though Yudhishthira tried to wriggle out of the trap set by Duryodhana and Shakuni
by refusing to play with Shakuni, Duryodhana, on the plea of playing himself made Shakuni
catch the dice on his behalf.
This distances between the two power- environments.
which was actually not according to the rules of the game but dhritarasana as the referee he did
not object to it and he did not give heat to yudhishtira's objection so yudhishtira was
forced to go along when the dice started rolling the stakes initially started with small things
some jewels some gold etc each time the dice would be rolled sakuni would win and yudhishtira would
lose gradually as the play progressed the stakes became bigger armies the different kinds of
weapons servants different soldiers etc etc the stakes kept getting bigger and bigger and each
time yudhishtira kept losing
finally a point of time came when yudhishtira had practically lost everything and then sakuni
incited him to bet his kingdom and yudhishtira having no other go he put his kingdom at stake
and played and yudhishtira lost that also now the whole assembly was abuzz
while all this was going on the people who are witnessing were not very happy with the way things
were proceeding they could see that the whole game was rigged but then dhritarashtra the emperor was
sitting there and he was not saying anything and the king's word is final so people did not know
what to do they were all talking amongst themselves like this the whole assembly was
then vidura started talking to dhritarashtra and he advised him in various ways that this was unfair
and it was not the right thing to do and viva could foresee that this is going to lead to the destruction
of the Kaurava dynasty because if by unfair means the pundavas unnecessarily the pandavas are angered
then eventually it would lead to war and if it led to war and the pandavas their power was so
their power they they were so mighty that the Kauravas would not be able to stand in front of
them Vidura very well knew this and he advised Dhritarashtra repeatedly to call off the match
but then he was Dhritarashtra was unwilling because Dhritarashtra was going on hearing
okay now they stake this they lost this they stake this they lost it now the kingdom has been staked
so Dhritarashtra was waiting because he was his greed was not allowing him to heed the words of
Vidura although he knew that Vidura meant well and whatever Vidura spoke were actually very
full of wisdom so Dhritarashtra impelled by his greed he refused to take action on Vidura's words
and so finally Yudhishthira Maharaj staked his kingdom and he lost the kingdom to
now what was left they were bereft of their kingdom nothing was left now the whole assembly
was completely they were they were all they were all shocked at what had happened and the
whole assembly fell pin drop silent now what is going to happen and then Duryodhana and Shakuni
started sarcastically needling Yudhishthira and
the
challenged him why don't you now now that you are lost everything you still have your brothers why
don't you try you try putting your brothers at stake maybe you can still win back you may be able
to win back everything that you have lost the gambling is such a such an activity that it is
very intoxicating it is like a whirlpool once a person enters into it it will suck that person
inside if a person keeps losing he will think keep thinking maybe just one
step next next time I may be able to win back everything so Yudhishthira also thought now what
to do the kingdom is lost everything is lost they are back on the streets the Pandavas are back on
the street so he put at stake Nakula and he lost Nakula also then Sahadeva Sahadeva also lost then
he staked Arjuna and he lost Arjuna also finally he staked Bhima very unwillingly
but with no other choice he staked Bhima and Bhima was also lost now the whole assembly fell
completely silent because what was happening because everyone could see what was happening
was not at all auspicious this was going to lead to something terrible everybody could sense it
then finally Yudhishthira Maharaj seeing no other go he stated himself
and he played one last attempt let me try one last time maybe I will be able to win back everything
and he staked himself and the dice was rolled and again Yudhishthira Maharaj was lost now he was
perspiring he did not know what to do everything had been lost according to the scheme according
to the trap laid by Duryodhana and Dhritarashtra Shakuni and others
now what to do he was completely downcast then Shakuni told him you still have one
chance what is that one chance why don't you stake Draupadi she is still there that's the last thing
you possess the whole assembly was an uproar how can Draupadi be staked how can she is the
daughter-in-law of the Kaurava household. How can her honor be put at stake? And now Vidura could
not tolerate it. He spoke very heavily against Duryodhana and told Dhritarashtra, please stop
this. Don't do this. Now, what happens is when Duryodhana heard this, Duryodhana could not
broke it, whatever Vidura was saying, and he started chastising him very severely,
reprimanding him very severely. Because it is said that,
if advice is given to a foolish person for his own welfare, instead of shanta,
instead of it making him peaceful, it will only anger him. An intelligent person,
when he receives the advice of a foolish person, he will only anger him.
When he receives good advice, he will take it very peacefully and he will dwell on it,
he will contemplate on it and try to make use of that advice. But a foolish person will think,
this advice is for my detrimental, it is detrimental to my interest. And when good
advice is given, he will not accept it. Duryodhana was like that. Despite Vidura's
so many good advice, he would never accept it. He always was under the impression that Vidura,
he is,
is partial towards the Pandavas and he does not think of my welfare. Although in reality Vidura
was talking for his own good. Duryodhana very severely reprimanded Vidura and Dhritarashtra
was silent. He did not take any action. So Vidura also felt silent because he also became
helpless. And so now Draupadi was put at stake. And again the dice was rolled. And like all the
previous times,
again Yudhishthira Maharaj lost. Now everything was gone. Nothing was left. The whole assembly
was completely in uproar. Nobody was happy with what was happening, except for three,
four people. Dushyasana, Karna, Duryodhana, Shakuni, Dhritarashtra. These were the only
people who were really happy. Nobody else was happy. Now Karna started remembering the
insult that Draupadi had made upon him in the Swayambhara where in front of everyone
she had said that Karna, because of being born in a Sudra family, he could not participate
in the Swayambhara. So he immediately told Duryodhana, now Draupadi is a slave. The Pandavas
have lost themselves. All the Yudhishthira and Bhima, Arjuna, Nakula, Sahadeva, all the
Pandavas have lost themselves. Now Duryodhana, Karna, Duryodhana, Shakuni, Dhritarashtra,
Karna, Arjuna, Nakula, Sahadeva, all the Pandavas have lost themselves. They are all our slaves.
And even Draupadi has been lost in the game of dice. So bring her, why she should stay
in the royal household. Please bring her and let us send her to the quarters, the servant's
quarters. Let her stay with all the maidservants. So our servant was sent to bring Draupadi
from her inner chambers. Now Draupadi had not dressed herself yet. Generally when we
we are at home, we will be wearing some casual dress, we will not be wearing our formal dress.
So Draupadi was in her casual dress, she was not planning to come out, so she was not dressed
formally.
So she was not in a position to come to the assembly when called for and when she heard
from the messenger that like this, in the game of dice, Yudhishthira Maharaj had lost
all the brothers.
He had lost himself and he had lost Draupadi also and now Draupadi was told to come to
the assembly so that she could be sent to the servant's quarters.
She sent the messenger back with a question asking whether she had been fairly lost in
the bet, whether she had been fairly lost in the game of dice.
Did Yudhishthira stake her and lose her and then he lost himself or he first staked himself
and then he lost himself.
He staked Draupadi later in which case the whole, his losing Draupadi becomes questionable.
Now when the messenger came back and asked this question, nobody had a proper answer.
So Duryodhana told Dushyasana, what is all this, you know asking various people to bring
her, you go and bring her.
So Dushyasana forcibly entered into the women's quarters.
Actually men are not supposed to enter the women's quarters.
Enter into the women's section of the palace wherever they are staying.
The men's and the women's quarters would be completely different.
But he forcibly entered there, caught hold of Draupadi by her hair, by her tresses and
he started dragging her to the assembly.
Draupadi was, she was objecting, she was saying, I am not dressed properly, I can't come in
this state.
There are so many elderly people like Bhishma, Drona, Dhritarashtra, all such personalities,
all such personalities.
They are there.
How can I come like this?
But he would not listen.
He just dragged her forcibly into the assembly and pulled her on the floor of the assembly.
And when Bhishma saw this, when Drona saw this, when Vidura saw this, they were beside
themselves with tears.
Actually it was not an insult of Draupadi, it was an insult of the entire Kaurava dynasty.
Duryodhana did not understand this.
Dhritarashtra was not willing to listen.
He was not willing to go against Duryodhana.
Now who is going to stop them?
Vidura is trying his best.
Dhritarashtra would not listen to Vidura, nor would he listen to Bhishma, nor would he
listen to Drona.
He would not listen to anyone except Duryodhana.
So, everybody, nobody knew what to do.
Everybody was beside themselves and the assembly, big furor in the assembly.
How can Draupadi be brought here?
So many people were objecting.
Some people were speaking in favor of Duryodhana.
Some people were objecting.
And when she was brought like this, then Duryodhana started telling her, now your husbands have
lost you.
Now you are a slave.
You please go to the servants quarters and be with the maid servants.
And then Karna told her, told Draupadi, Draupadi, now all your husbands, they have all lost
you.
They have all become our slaves.
Now you pick up somebody else as your husband.
These people are no more your slaves.
And these people are no more your husbands.
Like this, such piercing words were being used.
Draupadi was weeping and she was inconsolable.
And she looked at Drona, she looked at Bhishma, Vidura, none of them are saying anything.
Then she started talking to Dhritarashtra, oh my king, what is this?
The honor of the entire Kaurava dynasty is being brought to the, in front of all the
public like this?
Is this the way to treat Dhritarashtra?
Is this the way to treat the women folk of the Kaurava dynasty?
Dhritarashtra was silent.
Then she asked Dhritarashtra, please tell me, if Yudhishthira Maharaj had lost himself
before staking me, then how is it right for him to stake me further and then lose me?
Because he has already lost himself.
He is no more in a position to stake anybody else.
Now she asked Bhishma.
Bhishma said, my dear daughter, I am unable to answer you because although Yudhishthira
lost himself first and in one sense what you are saying is right, at the same time, no
matter in what situation a man is, his wife is still his own.
Just because Yudhishthira lost himself in the bed doesn't mean that he lost you also.
Even after he became the slave of the Kauravas, of Duryodhana and others, he is still your
husband.
And so he had the right to stake you.
So this is also there.
At the same time, this logic is also there that Yudhishthira, having staked himself,
had no more right to continue playing.
So I am confused.
I am not able to give a proper answer.
And so now there was nobody was able to say anything.
At that time.
At that time, one of Duryodhana's brothers, Vikarna, he stood up and he objected.
He said, Draupadi, her honor is being put on the floor like this.
I am not for this.
He objected very strongly.
And he said, according to me, Yudhishthira Maharaj, the one, the moment he had lost himself
in the game of dice, the game of dice was over.
There was no more question of betting and there was no more question of further staking
Draupadi.
So Draupadi is not lost.
She cannot be brought into the ashram.
She cannot be made a maid servant.
I oppose this.
Vikarna spoke very strongly, although he was a younger brother of Duryodhana.
And when Karna saw this, he flared up and he started rebuking Vikarna like anything.
And then Karna did something unthinkable.
Karna told Dushyasana, Dushyasana, what is this Draupadi is going on talking so many
things and she is asking for justice and all that.
After all, she is a woman who has married five men.
She has married five men as husband.
Does any respectable woman do that?
I think what you should do is disrobe her.
Let her become naked.
What she is talking so much about her honor and all that.
Like this, Karna incited Dushyasana and Dushyasana also.
He was also a wild man.
Immediately, he was also waiting for an opportunity.
Immediately, he caught hold of Draupadi's sari and started pulling at it.
Now Bhima.
He was waiting.
He was beside himself with fury.
He could not control himself.
But then what to do?
He was bound by his elder brother's words.
And his elder brother, because he is so much fixed in virtuosity and dharma that he is not
going to go against his word.
He had already given his word.
He had lost himself and his brothers.
So he was not in a position to say anything against what Duryodhana and others were saying
because they were now their slaves.
So Yudhishthira Maharaj could not say anything.
He could not do anything.
And Bhima was bound by his words.
And Arjuna started pacifying Bhima.
Calm down.
Calm down.
Don't become too angry now.
Now is not the right time.
Our hands are tied.
So like this, Arjuna was constantly pacifying Bhima.
And so now, the brothers were not able to do anything.
And in the whole assembly, Dushyasana started trying to pacify Bhima.
She started trying to strip Draupadi by pulling at her saree.
And Draupadi, she is trying to protect herself.
She is trying to protect her honor.
She is holding on with great effort to her, with great strength to her saree.
But this man, Dushyasana is such a well-built, powerful guy.
And Draupadi is such a delicate woman.
She is a delicate princess.
What she will fight against this,
this bulky, hefty man full of muscles and full of strength.
So she tried her best to hold the saree but she was not able to.
And she saw that her husbands are not in a position to help her.
She saw that the entire assembly, nobody is speaking against this injustice.
So what to do now?
Then she remembered one person who is the refuge of all people
who are completely shelterless.
That is the Supreme Personality of God and Lord Krishna.
So she started calling out to Krishna.
Krishna! Krishna!
She started calling out.
But then this Dushyasana is not giving up.
She is holding on.
She is calling out to Krishna but nothing is happening.
Then finally she realized,
I am holding on to this saree with all my effort.
But ultimately I cannot protect myself.
In this assembly when such big, big people are there,
my husbands are such great heroes, such great warriors,
they are not able to protect me.
What? I will protect myself.
My only shelter is Lord Krishna.
So she let go of her saree.
She raised her hands and started calling out,
O Govinda! O Gopijanavallada! O Hari Murari!
Like that she started calling out to Krishna.
The moment she started calling out to Krishna,
Krishna, although you are so far away in Dwaraka,
but then Krishna, as he says in the Bhagavad Gita,
Sarvasya Chaham Hrithi Sannivishtaha
Krishna is seated in every living entity's heart as Paramatma.
So the moment she gave up everything else,
her dependence on her husbands,
her dependence on her own abilities,
she gave up everything and totally surrendered to Krishna.
Krishna as Paramatma immediately sensed that surrender
and although Krishna was not there,
Krishna was seated in Dwaraka.
He knew everything of what was happening.
And then he remembered his promise to Draupadi
for the service that she had rendered to him.
And Krishna decided now is the time to repay the debt to Draupadi.
And so what happened?
After that, Dushyasana pulled and pulled and pulled at her saree.
The saree just kept coming and coming
and the yards and the yards of cloth is being piled up on the floor.
The cloth is piling on.
Minute after minute, hour after hour he is pulling.
Only the cloth is piling up but Draupadi is not getting disrobed.
And pulling, pulling, pulling, finally what happened?
Dushyasana lost all his strength and his stamina came to an end
and he sat down on the floor perspiring in the midst of all the cloth.
He was not able to understand what is happening,
from where all this cloth is coming.
And the whole assembly erupted in an uproar
when they saw this wonderful miracle that was happening.
Everybody understood how Krishna had saved the honour of Draupadi.
So now the Vidura and Bhishma,
they were all, they understood that somehow by Krishna's mercy this has happened
and now Krishna is not going to keep quiet.
So they became even more alarmed and they started advising Dhritarashtra
at least now please stop all these injustices that's happening.
How can the Kaurava assembly be sullied by trying to outrage the modesty of a woman?
That too not an ordinary woman.
She is one of the women folk of our own dynasty.
How can this happen?
How can you allow this to happen?
Their fervent pleas were falling on deaf ears.
Dhritarashtra had not only become blind,
he had become deaf also.
Now when Dushyasana failed in disrobing Draupadi
and when Duryodhana saw all this
and the Pandavas were so angry,
Bhima, now he was not able to check his anger
and Bhima when he saw how Dushyasana had tried to outrage the modesty of Draupadi,
he looked at Dushyasana and he took a vow,
a terrible vow,
a vow which swore
a vow so terrible,
nobody had heard of such a vow before.
He said in a raised voice,
his eyes red with fury,
Bhima said,
listen everyone,
I take a vow before everyone.
In battle,
I will tear open the chest of Dushyasana
and I will drink his blood.
When the assembly heard this,
Bhishma, Drona,
they were all struck with fear.
But Duryodhana,
like a fool,
like a fly which foolishly it rushes into a blazing fire,
oblivious of the fact that the flame is going to consume it,
Duryodhana was laughing.
And then he exposed this right thigh
and slapping his thigh,
Duryodhana told Draupadi,
come, come, my dear woman,
come and sit on my thigh.
Now Bhima, already he was curious
when he saw this,
his rock completely exceeded all limits.
Then he said,
I am taking one more vow.
In battle,
I will break that thigh of yours
and I will teach you a lesson.
When this much happened,
suddenly somehow Dhritarashtra,
he came to his senses
and he realized that this is going too far.
Finally, Dhritarashtra spoke.
What did Dhritarashtra speak?
What were his words?
Please join us in the next episode of the Mahabharata
to learn about this.
Thank you.
Hare Krishna.
